subject: Kingsley "ooze" character
msgSnippet: Thank you for your comment on the kingsley font. I do not have access to an Apple computer so I was unable to test either the kwikskript font or kingsley font
messageBody:
Thank you for your comment on the kingsley font.

I do not have access to an Apple computer so I was unable to test
either the kwikskript font or kingsley font on one before submitting
them to this group.

Does letter #39 ("f-OO-t") & the ligerature "you" also seem thinner /
lighter in kingsley when used on an Apple computer? At what font sizes
does this thinness / lightness appear more evident or least evident?

Without readily available access to an Apple computer, there is not
much I can do, save increasing the thickness of the character further.
While there may be slight variations of thickness from character to
character, I do not remember the character being designed
significantly thinner / lighter then the other characters.

Has anyone else experienced this phenomenon?

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "oliver langan" <yahoo@l...>
wrote:
> I use a Mac, and all of the QA fonts I have downloaded from the
forum so far suffer
> from a similar problem: the "ooze" sound is much thinner/lighter
than the other
> characters. With the default anti-aliasing on Mac OS X and/or in
printing it often
> seems to disappear next to the other characters. Making it boldface
often fixes the
> problem, but not always and it is a pain in any case.
>
> I have seen this with jerome, junior, kwikskript, kingsley and QS2
block. The
> problems aren't noticeable when I use the (Win 98) PC at work.
>
> oliver

I do not have access to an Apple computer so I was unable to test
either the kwikskript font or kingsley font on one before submitting
them to this group.

Does letter #39 ("f-OO-t") & the ligerature "you" also seem thinner /
lighter in kingsley when used on an Apple computer? At what font sizes

Without readily available access to an Apple computer, there is not
much I can do, save increasing the thickness of the character further.
While there may be slight variations of thickness from character to
character, I do not remember the character being designed
significantly thinner / lighter then the other characters.

Has anyone else experienced this phenomenon?
